fn main() {
    let mut file = std::fs::File::open("file.gz").unwrap();
    let file = libflate::gzip::Decoder::new(&mut file).unwrap();
    do_something_with(file);
};

item.title: Rust 'collect' function rocks!
item.description:
Here is one way to populate a Vec with some data:

let mut vector = Vec::new();
for n in 0..COUNT {
    vector.push(n);
};

Alternatively, one can simply do this:

let vector = (0..COUNT).collect::<Vec<_>>()

The function is also about twice as fast, according to the following benchmark …

Following should be self-explanatory:

$ python
>>> numbers = dict(zero=0, one=1, two=2, three=3)
>>> numbers
{'three': 3, 'zero': 0, 'two': 2, 'one': 1}
>>> sorted(numbers)
['one', 'three', 'two', 'zero']
>>> sorted(numbers, key=numbers.get)
['zero', 'one', 'two', 'three']

item.title: basic ConfigParser usage
item.description:
Reading .INI files is very easy with Python. Say you had a file, "config.cfg", with this content:

[numbers]
one: 1
two: 2

The code to read that content is:

import configparser
conf = configparser.ConfigParser()
conf.read("config.cfg")
items = conf.items("numbers")
print(items)

Output:

[('one', '1'), ('two', '2' …

mkdir dir

Here's another way to delete it:

rm -r dirlink/

Although it will do the job, it will actually complain with:

rm: cannot remove `dirlink': Not a directory
